title: Bids submitted for consideration at the "Go Local" funding initiative

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please can I have copies of all the 338 bids that were submitted for consideration for go-local funding in 2012.  Please can you indicate which bids were Rejected, Area approved, approved for voting events	and the outcome as decided by voting.
Yours faithfully,
M. McCullagh

Re – Freedom of Information Request – Reference – FOI / 1596
Dear M. McCullagh
Thank you for your recent request for information relating to Bids
submitted for consideration at the "Go Local" funding initiative which we
received on 04/03/2015.
This has been logged as a Freedom of Information Request, and will be
dealt with under the Freedom of Information Act.  The reference number for
your request can be found above.
The Freedom of Information Act states that we must respond to you within
20 working days, therefore, you should expect to hear a response from us
by 01/04/2015.
In the meantime, if you have any queries please contact me on 0114
2734567.
Thank you.
Yours sincerely,
FOI Support Team
Moorfoot Level 8 West Wing
Sheffield S1 4PL
Tel : 0114 20 53478

Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please pass this on to the person who conducts Freedom of Information reviews.
I am writing to request an internal review of Sheffield City Council's handling of my FOI request 'Bids submitted for consideration at the "Go Local" funding initiative'.
I am asking pertinent questions that scrutinize the council as is my right under the tenant involvement and empowerment standard and under the freedom of information act.
I am trying to determine if the Bids presented at the Go Local funding initiative adequately explained the nature of the CCTV installs that were approved as part of the Go Local funding initiative. They should have included as a minimum details of the locations of the cameras, details of the type of information recorded, details about the purposes for which the data would be used.
I think this is a reasonable request to make during the course of scrutinizing the council over what I beleive to be an inadequate consultation with residents.
I have made a total of 27 freedom of information requests since June 2014. That is an average of 2.7 requests per month or just over 1 every fortnight. I do not think this is unreasonable.
My requests do overlap only slighty because I'm trying to get to the bottom of the CCTV install at Brightmore Drive. However I have not repeated the same request once it has been refused. By asking about Go-lacal" funding, "privacy impact assemsments" and the "IKMT" I am keeping my requests focussed on the issue without repeating the same questions more than once. I do not think my requests overlap and all of these requests are pertinent to an investigation in to the conditions that resulted in the CCTV installation.
I wish to challenge the determiniation that my requests are vexatious. I  understand that you do not wish to answer these questions because they are embarrasing for the council, however you are required by law to answer my requests.
The reasons you have stated for determining my requests to be vexasious numbers 1-7 are entirely false. The council cannot hide behind this exemption to avoid answering ligitimate questions from concerned members of the public.
A full history of my FOI request and all correspondence is available on the Internet at this address:
https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/b...
Yours faithfully,
M. McCullagh

Reference:        1596
Dear Mr McCullagh,
I am writing in connection with the Freedom of Information request you
submitted on 4^th March 2015 (our reference 1596):
In your request, you specifically asked for:
Please can I have copies of all the 338 bids that were submitted for
consideration for go-local funding in 2012.  Please can you indicate which
bids were Rejected, Area approved, approved for voting events        and
the outcome as decided by voting.
I have carried out an Internal Review of the handling of your request. I
was not party to the original decision on whether the information you
requested should be released. Please take this letter as the response to
your Internal Review.
The intention of an internal review is to consider if we handled your
response in accordance with the law and to consider if any decisions made,
for example to refuse information, were correct and still apply.
In my review of the processing of this request I have considered:
·        Your original request
·        The response to your request
Time for Compliance
Section 10 – Time for compliance with request
([1]
http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2000...
)
Section 10 of the Freedom of Information Act states that Sheffield City
Council must respond to requests made under the Freedom of Information Act
within 20 working days of receipt. In this case, your request was received
by Sheffield City Council on 4^th March 2015 which was responded to on
4^th March 2015 in a letter from Mark Knight, Information Management
Officer and followed up with an email to whatdotheyknow.com for this case
on the 6^th March 2015. This response was provided within 20 working days,
therefore, I am satisfied that Section 10 of the Freedom of Information
Act was correctly complied with in this case.
The exemption(s) which were applied to the information you requested
Section 14 – Vexatious requests
([2]
http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2000...
)
Have the exemptions been correctly applied in this case?
·        Section 14 (1) – Vexatious requests
The explanation why this exemption applied was provided to you in your
original response as detailed in full in our letter of the 4^th March
2015.
Although section 14(1) of the FOIA is not in Part II ‘Exempt Information’
of the FOIA, its application has the effect of enabling a public authority
to refuse to supply information that has been requested under the FOIA and
so we have
described this section as an ‘exemption’.
The starting point for the consideration of internal reviews is to
determine whether the exemptions cited in refusal letters are engaged and,
if so, whether, in respect of non-absolute exemptions, the public interest
test has been applied correctly.
We have considered your request in accordance with the Information
Commissioner’s Office (ICO) guidance on vexatious requests. Having
undertaken such consideration when handling your initial request and under
this review we are firmly of the view that your request is vexatious and
section 14(1) was applied correctly for the reasons set out in our letter
of 4^th March 2015.
Link to the ICO’s guidance:
[3]
https://ico.org.uk/media/for-organisatio...
Application of the Public Interest Test
Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, there are two types of
exemption, “Qualified Exemptions” and “Absolute Exemptions”. When applying
an exemption to information that is requested, if the exemption is a
“Qualified Exemption”, then we are required to carry out a Public Interest
Test. If any exemption applies which is “Absolute”, there is no
requirement for us to carry out a Public Interest Test.
In relation to your request, Section 14 is not subject to a Public
Interest Test.
Response to further comments in your request for review
Within your request for review you noted some specific concerns as
detailed below and responded to:
I am asking pertinent questions that scrutinize the council as is my right
under the tenant involvement and empowerment standard and under the
freedom of information act.
The application of Section 14 removes the requirement to provide
information under the Freedom of Information Act. Other standards do not
impact on the disclosure decision made under FOI.
I have made a total of 27 freedom of information requests since June 2014.
That is an average of 2.7 requests per month or just over 1 every
fortnight. I do not think this is unreasonable.
The ICO guidance noted about does allow the Council to consider the
aggregated impact of requests as noted in point 56:
56. A request which would not normally be regarded as vexatious in
isolation may assume that quality once considered in context. An example
of this would be where an individual is placing a significant strain on an
authority’s resources by submitting a long and frequent series of
requests, and the most recent request, although not obviously vexatious in
itself, is contributing to that aggregated burden.
The method of determining this aggregated burden is not specifically
defined by the ICO and therefore the Council defines what it feels is a
burden upon it.
My requests do overlap only slighty because I'm trying to get to the
bottom of the CCTV install at Brightmore Drive. However I have not
repeated the same request once it has been refused. By asking about
Go-lacal" funding, "privacy impact assemsments" and the "IKMT" I am
keeping my requests focussed on the issue without repeating the same
questions more than once. I do not think my requests overlap and all of
these requests are pertinent to an investigation in to the conditions that
resulted in the CCTV installation.
As detailed with our letter of the 4^th March 2015 we believe that grounds
are sufficient to make this and associated requests vexatious as confirmed
in this internal review.
I wish to challenge the determiniation that my requests are vexatious. I
understand that you do not wish to answer these questions because they are
embarrasing for the council, however you are required by law to answer my
requests.
The application of Section 14 removes the requirement to provide
information under the Freedom of Information Act. The reasons for our
refusal were clearly outlined in our letter of the 4^th March 2015,
embarrassment was not a factor in our decision making process.
The reasons you have stated for determining my requests to be vexasious
numbers 1-7 are false. The council cannot hide behind this exemption to
avoid answering ligitimate questions from concerned members of the public.
The application of Section 14 removes the requirement to provide
information under the Freedom of Information Act.
Review Decision - Conclusion
Taking the above into account, I am satisfied that the following exemption
applies to the information that you have requested:
o Section 14
In conclusion, it is my view that your Freedom of Information request has
been handled correctly and within the legal requirements of the Freedom of
Information Act 2000.
I realise this is not the decision that you would wish, but I hope you can
understand why I have upheld the original refusal to provide you with the
details you have requested.
If you are dissatisfied with the outcome, you are entitled to contact the
Information Commissioner’s Office and they will consider whether your
complaint is eligible for further review. The Information Commissioner’s
details and guidance is available on the website at [4]www.ico.org.uk.
Yours sincerely,
Charlotte Mead
Housing Co-ordinator (Housing Freedom of Information and Subject Access
Requests)
Information and Knowledge Management Team
Resources, Sheffield City Council
Telephone: 0114 2930000
Website:
www.sheffield.gov.uk
